questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the BRCA1 gene. Which of the following best describes the function of BRCA1?

options.label: A
options.text: Encodes a cell surface receptor for growth factors

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Repairs double-strand DNA breaks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The BRCA1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a crucial role in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 80fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Serum ferritin levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The next best investigation for microcytic hypochromic anemia is serum ferritin levels , as it is the most sensitive marker for iron deficiency anemia.
  • ➤ next best investigation for microcytic hypochromic anemia is serum ferritin levels
  • ➤ The Menzer index formula (MCV/RBC count) is used for differentiating between IDA and thalassemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 150,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FISH and PCR tests are the most sensitive and specific investigations for diagnosing CML by detecting the Philadelphia chromosome and BCR-ABL fusion gene. PCR is also critical for monitoring minimal residual disease during treatment.
  • ➤ FISH and PCR tests are the most sensitive and specific investigations for diagnosing CML

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a family history of endocrine tumors presents with recurrent episodes of peptic ulcers and diarrhea. Further evaluation reveals hypercalcemia and elevated levels of gastrin, insulin, and prolactin. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the MEN1 gene. Which of the following best explains the mechanism underlying the patient's symptoms?

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of function of the menin protein

questions.correct_answer: C. Loss of function of the menin protein
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Loss of function of the menin protein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MEN1 syndrome is caused by loss of function of the menin protein , leading to tumors in the parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas. MEN1 is distinct from MEN2, which is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene.
  • ➤ loss of function of the menin protein

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?

options.label: A
options.text: Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

options.label: B
options.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

options.label: C
options.text: There is loss of function type of mutation

options.label: D
options.text: There are abnormal repeats of CUG

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder involving CAG repeats on chromosome 4. It leads to a gain-of-function mutation, causing a toxic protein that results in neurodegeneration and anticipation across generations.
  • ➤ Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder involving CAG repeats on chromosome 4. It leads to a gain-of-function mutation, causing a toxic protein that results in neurodegeneration and anticipation across generations.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathology are pathognomonic for papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common thyroid malignancy. Early diagnosis ensures excellent prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nitric oxide? NO relaxes vascular smooth muscle and cause vasodilation NO helps in generation of free radicals in neutrophil at the time of inflammation Interferon-γ (IFN-γ) or microbial products can activate inducible NOS Synthesis of NO requires NOS action on arginine.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Only 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NO contributes to reactive nitrogen species formation, its direct involvement in neutrophil free radical production is limited.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed for the condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He is having hyperpigmentation on the skin and higher risk for development of skin cancer as per his physician. Which of the following is a likely enzyme defect in the patient?

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair gene defect

questions.text: A middle-aged lady has diarrhea and abdominal flatulence for last 3 months. Her intestinal biopsy demonstrated villous atrophy and serum had the Anti - TTG antibodies present in it. Which of the following is the safest food for this individual?

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with morning headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, there is truncal ataxia and signs of increased intracranial pressure. MRI reveals a midline mass in the cerebellum with heterogeneous enhancement. A biopsy is performed, and histological examination shows small, round, blue cells with Homer-Wright rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Medulloblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, typically presenting as a midline cerebellar mass with characteristic small, round, blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes on histology.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with a four-day history of cough, fever, and shortness of breath. The cough is productive of yellowish sputum. On physical examination, decreased breath sounds are auscultated on the right lower lung field, and dullness to percussion is noted in the same area. Antibiotics were started by the physician and he stated improving. Which of the following cytokines will most likely be seen in the resolution phase of bacterial pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IL-10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IL-10 plays a central role in resolving inflammation during the recovery phase of infections such as bacterial pneumonia. It achieves this by suppressing pro-inflammatory cytokines and facilitating tissue repair.
  • ➤ IL-10
  • ➤ Anti-inflammatory cytokines predominate in the resolution phase of bacterial pneumonia. Anti-inflammatory cytokines are IL-4, IL-10, IL-13, TGF -beta and Lipoxins

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is found to have mild hypertension. Laboratory findings show a serum creatinine level of 2.2 mg/dL Microalbuminuria is present, A renal biopsy is done; the light microscopic appearance of a PAS- stained specimen is shown in the figure. Blood/serum test for which of the following is most likely to be abnormal in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemoglobin A1c

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nodular and diffuse glomerulosclerosis, characterized by Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, is a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy. Hemoglobin A1c is the key test to monitor glycemic control and prevent further renal damage.
  • ➤ Nodular and diffuse glomerulosclerosis, characterized by Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, is a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy. Hemoglobin A1c is the key test to monitor glycemic control and prevent further renal damage.
  • ➤ The figure shows nodular and diffuse glomerulosclerosis that often occur in patients with long-standing DM which is often complicated by UTIs. Infections with bacterial organisms also occur more frequently in patients with diabetes mellitus who have an elevated Hb A1c.
  • ➤ nodular and diffuse glomerulosclerosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of IBD presents with elevated liver enzymes. On imaging, multifocal strictures and dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are noted. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and hypergammaglobulinemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates onion-skin fibrosis around small- and medium-sized bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is strongly associated with inflammatory bowel disease and characterized by bile duct strictures, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and onion-skin fibrosis.
  • ➤ Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with gastrointestinal bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). Thromboelastography (TEG) is performed and shows a prolonged reaction time (R-time), decreased angle (α-angle), and reduced maximum amplitude (MA). Which of the following best explains these TEG findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypocoagulability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Liver cirrhosis leads to hypocoagulability due to reduced production of clotting factors and thrombopoietin. TEG findings in this setting include prolonged R-time, decreased α-angle, and reduced MA.
  • ➤ Liver cirrhosis

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with flank pain and hematuria. CT imaging reveals a solid renal mass located in the upper pole of the left kidney. Biopsy of the mass shows clear cytoplasm with numerous lipid droplets and cells arranged in a nested pattern. Which of the following is the expected finding on genetic analysis from his sample?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chromosome 3p deletion

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common type of RCC and is characterized by chromosome 3p deletion involving the VHL gene .
  • ➤ Clear cell renal cell carcinoma
  • ➤ chromosome 3p deletion
  • ➤ VHL gene

questions.text: A newborn Chhoti is brought to the clinic due to jaundice shortly after birth. The infant appears otherwise healthy, and physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests reveal elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels in the blood. Further investigation shows a deficiency of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT) enzyme activity. Which of the following conditions best describes the underlying cause of the infant's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Crigler-Najjar syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency or complete absence of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT) enzyme activity.

questions.text: A 17-year-old presented with intussusceptions and was found to be having a polyp. A biopsy is taken and is shown alongside. What is the likely correct statement about this condition?

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with chronic fatigue. Physical examination reveals slight jaundice and splenomegaly. The results of laboratory studies include hemoglobin of 11.8g/dL, hematocrit of 30%, total bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dL, and conjugated bilirubin of 0.8 mg/dL. questions.text: An elderly patient was admitted in the ICU of a hospital for last 10 days. He complained of respiratory distress and collapsed in 15 minutes. On autopsy, his lungs had an appearance as shown. Which of the following is not true about his condition?

questions.text: Risk of HIV transmission is not seen with:
questions.correct_answer: C. Plasma derived Hepatitis B vaccine
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Plasma derived Hepatitis B vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasma-derived vaccines undergo rigorous processing to eliminate any potential viral contaminants, making them safe and free of HIV transmission risks. Conversely, whole blood, platelets, and leucocytes can potentially transmit HIV if contaminated.

questions.text: Autoimmunity in EBV infection is the result of:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with painless lymphadenopathy, night sweats, and weight loss. A lymph node biopsy is done following which a diagnosis of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma is made. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department with sudden shortness of breath. He also complains of abdominal pain and few episodes of vomiting. questions.text: A pathologist is examining the liver biopsy of a 20-year-old male with cirrhosis. A Prussian blue stain reveals extensive positivity. Laboratory testing does not reveal HbH or Hb Barts. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  β-thalassemia major

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with a severe headache, tenderness over the temples, and vision changes, including sudden, painless, and complete loss of vision in one eye. questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Urgent treatment with corticosteroids is critical to prevent bilateral vision loss. Diagnosis is confirmed by temporal artery biopsy and elevated ESR/CRP levels.
